body: I was able to use local changes in THRIFT-4780 to prove this is not necessary; nodejs is sending sequence numbers just fine.

@nsuke: notsutre what you mean by "drop" exactly: only for C++and py? For all? 

Either way, I still would hesitate to agree. If the HTTP transport needs a reply because HTTP requires it - well, fine.  But that should not affect Thrifts `oneway` semantics: no return value, not even an exception. 

This is from the Whitepaper (`oneway` was called `async` back then)

> Note that void is a valid type for a function return, in addition
> to all other defined Thrift types. Additionally, an async modifier
> keyword may be added to a void function, which will generate
> code that does not wait for a response from the server. Note that a
> pure void function will return a response to the client which guarantees
> that the operation has completed on the server side. With
> async method calls the client will only be guaranteed that the request
> succeeded at the transport layer. (In many transport scenarios
> this is inherently unreliable due to the Byzantine Generals’ Problem.
> Therefore, application developers should take care only to use
> the async optimization in cases where dropped method calls are
> acceptable or the transport is known to be reliable.)

Properties of a oneway request, commonly known as a fire-and-forget message:

- The client may throw an exception during the request call due to protocol or transport level issues in communicating with the server.
- If the transport requires it, a successful but otherwise empty response will be immediately sent on receipt of the oneway request.  In this case the transport must not delay the reply until the RPC is processed (this is what the Java cross test client is testing for).
- There is no thrift protocol level reply from the server.  This means any exception generated by the server will be dropped.  (Perhaps it should be logged, but that's a separate discussion).

I haven't looked, but is there a HTTP mode where the client can tell the server no reply is necessary?  From memory there is no such thing, but things change... At my last company the entire networking layer between systems relied on the "async" philosophy, leaving the application layer responsible to check on and potentially retry idempotent behavior.  It can lead to a more scalable design.
This pull request does what Jens suggests, at least for the THttpServer class we provide for Python.  I suppose we should be doing the same thing to the others.
I created THRIFT-4798 to track this for the release notes.
Going to close this, we'll end up redoing it anyway for cmake.  Thanks for the pull request though!

> I'm kind of confused - we have lib/js, lib/nodejs, lib/ts, and lib/nodets. I don't know which ones are valid and active any more?

`lib/js` and `lib/nodejs`  are for using Thrift on the browser and on nodejs, respectively, via JavaScript.

`lib/ts` and `lib/nodets` are for using Thrift on the browser and nodejs, repectively, via Typescript. 

Some of these directories contain source code and tests. IMO, the following changes should be made, but I am not 100% sure:

- `lib/js` contains `src/thrift.js` (JS code for Thrift library for the browser). I don't see this file being included in the Thrift npm package. So this file seems unused. Instead, the Thrift npm package includes the JS code for nodejs, but to make it usable from the browser, in package.json, it specifies a 'browser' field. This field points to a browser.js file, which defines a subset of the nodejs code to be activated in the browser. IMO, the directory `src` under `lib/js` is unused. Most likely it should be removed. But the tests should stay.
 
- `lib/nodejs` contains `lib/thrift` (JS code for Thrift library for nodejs) and tests. This looks fine to me.

- `lib/ts` contains `thrift.d.ts` (type mappings for the `lib/js/src/thrift.js`). This is another confusion point. As of now, Thrift type mappings seem to come from DefinitelyTyped (https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/types/thrift/index.d.ts). So I am not sure what this file is used for. This directory also contains tests, which seems fine to me.

- `lib/nodets` only contains tests, which seems fine.

@jeking3

@jeking3 @bgedik 

It would be nice if we can extend the current `thrift.d.ts` and configure it in the package.json's `types` so we won't need to use the one in the DefinetelyTyped -seems like it is not maintained very well.
The existing `thrift.d.ts` would need to move under `lib/nodejs`.
In the original PR the author didn't know why readI64 was coming up as undefined.  The test module in question (test/binary_test.js) is testing lib/thrift/binary.js which has no readI64.
Well I spent some time with this, it doesn't seem to be trivial.  I'm closing this and if someone wants to pick it up, feel free.

I have been looking at the pull request for THRIFT-4214.  It looks like node-Int64 does NOT allow for 64-bit mathematics in node.  It is really not much more than a buffer.  Another package, bignum, lets you do the integer math.  Do we really want to force folks to use a 64-bit integer package that can't do 64-bit integer math?  The cross tests simply spit back what they were passed.  It's an unlikely scenario for an actual user of Thrift.

Is anybody interested in reworking this to use bignum instead?

Thanks, Jim
I think we would be better off using bignum instead of node-int64 - the latter does not actually allow for 64-bit integer math.

I was under the assumption that THRIFT-4214 was already a breaking change.  I looked over the long package and it seems fine.  Similar to bignum in functionality, but it doesn't have the native library requirements (openssl).  bignum actually allows for numbers beyond 64-bit, which is not a requirement for us.

Is this work you could/would-like-to do?

@jeking3 Even before this change, Thrift was already using `node-int64` both in its generated code (for RPCs) and in its runtime library. This PR only added the same to generated constants. We kept `Int64` to be consistent with the rest of Thrift.

What you are suggesting is to change the entire `Int64` support with `Long`. This is certainly better. In fact, we use `Long` in our code base. Whether we are willing to contribute this or not is something we'll discuss and report back.
@jeking3 We won't be able to do this right away. However, we can come back to this once we have more resources.

As pointed out by @jeking3 [here](https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1758/files#r265942159), should I have simply created a TcpListener instance in the port only constructor? You wouldn't be able to rethrow an exception as a TTransportException, but is that a requirement?

In these cases I typically refactor the common initialization code to a single method and call that from both constructors.  It avoids future situations where someone modifies one constructor and not the other.  This typically happens when someone adds a variable and then forgets to initialize it in one of the constructors.  Some languages help protect against this, and it's been a while since I did any meaningful C#, so maybe that's not necessary and the compiler catches it?
@allengeorge there's an open question on this one.
@jeking3 before the fix. lua version can't send double to java or c# correctly 'cause the order issue. not sure other tests

I'd think that you would want to raise an exception if someone passed in a null TcpListener though.  I see what you mean though.  Anyway, it was just a thought.  It doesn't have to be done.  This is still an improvement as-is, I was just thinking about how to consolidate the initialization.

Our cross language tests send doubles from lua client to java server and back:

java-lua                binary            framed-ip                success
java-lua                binary            buffered-ip              success

On the client lua side here is the code:
https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/test/lua/test_basic_client.lua#L147

On the server java side here is the code:
https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/java/test/org/apache/thrift/server/ServerTestBase.java#L89

The reverse where Java is the client:
https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/java/test/org/apache/thrift/test/TestClient.java#L282

and lua is the server:
https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/test/lua/test_basic_server.lua#L57

HOWEVER we do not seem to be running any tests where lua is the server.  That's a bug, but I still feel the round trip from lua client through java server disproves what you said.

Is there something deficient in these tests we're missing?  We are proving that doubles successfully round-trip with these tests.  Are we testing enough values and enough boundaries to prove or disprove what you are saying?

@jeking3 the Initializer() way would be great, but we will have to sacrifice `readonly` then, since `readonly` vars can conly be set in a CTOR in C#. We could change these vars into R/O properties though.

Sorry for taking forever to get around to this. Aight, this opens up a big question: should we significantly bump the minimum Rust version? I'm actually OK with bumping it up to 1.33 because:

1. Most of the rust community moves pretty fast
2. This allows us to target Edition 2018
3. There are already a fair amount of breaking language changes in master (AFAIK)
4. I'd like to start adding futures support when it rolls around.
@dbcfd There's no need to specify edition 2018. I could be wrong, but I believe those two are orthogonal?
Confirmed: they are orthogonal. There's no need to specify Edition 2018, but, we will end up bumping min Rust version to 1.33

I'll close this PR in favor of creating a new one that reinstates the original modular design vision.

The build seems to have failed in the Haskell build for some reason. I'll rebase this after that issue is resolved.

This PR breaks compatibility with any build system that uses time stamps to check if a file needs to be regenerated (`make`, `ninja`, etc). If the `.thrift` file is touched, `make` correctly decides to re-run the thrift compiler. Thrift does not touch the generated files and next time `make` is run, the same thing happens again.

At the very least, this should have had a command line option to disable.
If the contents of the output files have not changed, why would you need to recompile?

Any timestamp based build system (like `make`) will see that the generated files are older than the `.thrift` file and that they need to be rebuilt. This is in the "contract" between `make` and the different tools it invokes - the compiler, the linker, etc - if told to do something, they will do it.
It's not that files need to be recompiled for the resulting executable to be correct, but it's a requirement for timestamp based build systems that the timestamp of the generated files are updated.

It looks like it doesn't work with the latest `network` (released in January). An easy fix would be to put an upper bound on it:

```
--- a/lib/hs/thrift.cabal
+++ b/lib/hs/thrift.cabal
@@ -42,7 +42,7 @@ Library
   Build-Depends:
     base >= 4, base < 5, containers, ghc-prim, attoparsec, binary, bytestring >= 0.10, base64-bytestring, hashable, HTTP, text, hspec-core > 2.4.0, unordered-containers >= 0.2.6, vector >= 0.10.12.2, QuickCheck >= 2.8.2, split
   if flag(network-uri)
-     build-depends: network-uri >= 2.6, network >= 2.6
+     build-depends: network-uri >= 2.6, network >= 2.6 && < 3.0
   else
      build-depends: network < 2.6
   Exposed-Modules:
```
